title: Hexdrinker and Seeker Armguard need more build paths
body:
Like the Haunting Guise and ~~Phage~~, the Hexdrinker and Seeker Armguard need more build paths, the enemy can predict your next item always that you have one of these items.

Edit: Phage have now Brutalizer, add now **the Brutalizer** instead.

replies.body: I think that those items are only there as means to upgrade into their respective items, and are strong enough as it is that they don't need a new path. The weakest of the items you listed probably is the Seeker's Armguard, only because it's passive doesn't carry over, so that one might have a purpose (give mages a little help vs AD Assassins). As for the rest of them, their early passives are very strong. The cheap Magic Pen. on Haunting Guise is extremely vital to AP Assassins. The Hexdrinker's passive is ludicrously strong for AD Assassins or Bruisers that fall behind to an AP champion. Phage is freaking Phage (Jax will forever stick to you until one of you die, and that would be you who will die).

> I think that those items are only there as means to upgrade into their respective items

Seeker's Armguard was specifically made as a component for Zhonya's Hourglass. It used to build out of Chain Vest instead, which wasn't a very comfortable recipe. At that time it was used to tune down the reign of Talon over the mid lane (the first wave, Talon briefly came back years later before they removed his silence).

> The cheap Magic Pen. on Haunting Guise is extremely vital to AP Assassins.

Actually it's even more so important for mage bruisers - champions who rely on their base damages rather than AP scalings.

Anyway, Haunting Guise existed in season 1 as an item without any upgrades - as did Chalice of Harmony. People didn't realize the power of the magic peentration and felt "trapped" with the item. It was also a time of Metagolem (Warmog's Armor had stacking HP and regen back then) and Liandry's Torment was one of the two anti-health tools introduced, the other one being Blade of the Ruined King.

> The Hexdrinker's passive is ludicrously strong for AD Assassins or Bruisers that fall behind to an AP champion.

Hexdrinker is a very similar case. It was a mid-tier standalone item without any upgrades.

They've actually tested an alternative upgrade to it, Spellbreaker (melee only, with Avarice Blade in recipe and Tenacity as its unique effect), but it didn't help melee carries and was abused by bruisers instead.

> Phage is freaking Phage

Phage is a bastard child of balancing Trinity Force. Any item with a slow strong enough to win you lane 1v1 is absurdly strong in teamifghts, since it's not just you catching up to the target, but everybody else.

So the RNG slow was removed and replaced with a speed boost, leaving Phage as a temporary solution that got left hanging for years because no better solution was found.

Honestly I think the whole item system needs an overhaul. There should be a standard of low tier items for each stat, similar to how it is now. Then those low tier items should combine for possible scenarios. Ex: low tier simply AP item + low tier mana regen item = mid tier AP and mana regen item, slightly stronger than both of the ingredients. Obviously the higher tier items would have unique effects, things like %health, slows on-hit etc. but this would allow items to be chosen based on situations and individual games rather than "I'm playing champion X so I have to build these items or I'm not viable".
